h i g h l i g h t s
The sample which has the largest permeability, had the minimum value of draindown. The effect of glass fiber in reducing the permeability is far greater than that of the basalt. The tensile strength of asphalt mixtures increases by adding fiber. The effect of nano-silica in reducing abrasion and reduction of sensitivity to oxidation is considerable.
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 22 October 2018 Received in revised form 3 February 2019 Accepted 2 April 2019
Keywords: OGFC Asphalt Basalt fibers Glass fibers Nano-silica Sensitivity Draindown
a b s t r a c t
Open-graded friction course (OGFC) is a mixture having gap graded aggregate which is used in pavement surfacing. Asphalt mixtures were modified by Nano silica, polymer, basalt fiber and glass fiber. A draindown test, Cantabro test, permeability test and an indirect tensile strength test and moisture susceptibility were used to evaluate the performance of OGFC mixtures. Test results revealed optimum compounds for 0.2% basalt fiber with 2% nano-silica and 4.5% Styrene-Butadiene Styrene (SBS) Polymer. The minimum air voids content of fiber-reinforced OGFC mixtures modified with nanomaterial should be 13% for 6% bitumen. The results showed the effect of nano-silica in reducing abrasion and reduction of sensitivity to oxidation is considerable and the effect of basalt fiber per 0.2% in the asphalt mixture to be greater than that of glass fiber in reducing the draindown phenomenon; and for controlling the level of draindown phenomenon, nano-silica compound should also be used with basalt fiber. It was also found that although the use of basalt fiber is more effective in decreasing draindown in comparison with glass fiber, the effect of glass fiber in reducing the permeability of the asphalt mixture is far greater than basalt fiber.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Open-graded friction course (OGFC) has been used since 1950 to improve the surface frictional resistance of asphalt pavements. Porous asphalt is superior to other asphalt surface layer types due to advantages such as improved surface frictional resistance, minimized hydroplaning, reduced splash and spray, improved night visibility, rapid drainage of surface water, low traffic noise, increased visibility of traffic signs as well as low glare reflections
[1–3]. Porous asphalt can provide numerous advantages on roadways. The increased air void content of OGFCs leads to interconnected permeable voids which create permeability in the surface layer, and allow air and water to flow towards the road sides [4]. Although porous asphalt has some advantages as mentioned above, its low strength against cracks and raveling is one of the disadvantages of this type of surface layer. One of the major objectives of using fibers in asphalt mixtures is not only to improve the fatigue and rutting performance, but also to increase raveling resistance and moisture susceptibility. The fibers firmly bind the aggregate particles inside the matrix and prevent moving them, which makes the mix stiffer [5–7]. The major part of porous
asphalt is formed by crushed relatively coarse aggregates. Permeable friction course (PFC) mixes have coarser grain size and have almost no middle grain and fine grains, while OGFC asphalt mixes have no fine aggregates. Moreover, the volumetric percentage of air void in the PFC asphalt mixture ranges from 18% to 22%, while it is equal to 10% to 15% for OGFC mixtures [6,8,9]. PFC mixed porous asphalt is used in common pavements in the form of a thin layer with a thickness of about 50 mm This type of mixture can provide frictional and safety benefits in wet and environmental conditions, and effectively deal with the excessive development [10–12]. OGFC mixtures improves driving in wet conditions by allowing the water to drain through its porous structure away from the roadway. Moisture can eliminate the adhesion between aggregates and bitumen and lead to stripping in the pavement.
According to the performed studies, fibers play a remarkable role in the gap-graded or PFC mixtures. The use of fibers alters the visco-elasticity characteristics of the mixture, enhancing its dynamic modulus, sensibility against humidity, flow coherence, and resistance against rutting; as well as decreasing the amount of reflective cracks in asphalt mixtures. Tanzadeh and Shahrezagamasaei investigated the effect of glass fiber, polypropylene fiber, as well as Lime and nano-silica powder on porous asphalt, and they found an enhancement in rutting and indirect tensile strength in the modified specimens. According to this research, glass and polypropylene fibers reduce the draindown phenomenon and increase the indirect tensile strength of the specimens [13]. Nihat Morova used Basalt Fiber to modify Hot Asphalt Concrete. 4.5%, 5% and 5.5% bitumen, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1, 1.5, and 2% basalt fibers and a total of 18 specimens were used in this study. According to the Marshall Stability tests, the best air and flow value percentages were obtained for 5% bitumen content and 0.50% basalt fiber addition [14]. Glass fibers increase the flow and elastic modulus of asphalt mixtures. The glass fiber in the asphalt mixture can also increase the marshal stability, flow and elastic modulus of the mixtures. Moreover glass-modified mixtures have lower permanent strain and higher fatigue and rutting resistance compared to unmodified asphalt mixtures [15]. Nanotechnology is the development of new materials, devices and systems at molecular level, a phenomenon associated with atomic and molecular interactions, which greatly affects the macroscopic properties of materials [16]. The effect of nanoparticles surface can be used to enhance the stability of modified asphalt. In recent years, nanotechnology has emerged in the form of a variety of asphalt modifying Nanomaterial used to modify mixtures [17–19]. Nano-silica increases the shear modulus and the viscosity of asphalt, which consequently increases the anti-aging performance, fatigue cracking performance, rutting resistance, and anti-abrasion properties of asphalt. Studies have shown that addition of 1 to 2% nano-silica to asphalt mixtures leads to reduced penetration and flexibility, increased softening point, increased elastic strain and also increased sensitivity to high temperature [20,21] On the other hand, over the last decade, Nano-Silica (NS) has gained great attention by pavement researchers in the preparation of asphaltic materials with desirable properties because of its excellent stability, low cost, high surface area, chemical purity, strong adsorption, and good dispersing ability [22,23]. In a study by Hassani et al., it was indicated that adding nano-silica material to the asphalt mixtures increased the indirect tensile strength of a specimen. Therefore, the asphalt mixture became more resistant against cracks [24]. Nur Izzi Md et al. found that adding nano-silica material to asphalt mixture makes them more resistant against cracks and raveling [25]. In another study, Jamshidi et al. figured out that adding 4% and 6% nano-silica to bitumen reduces the asphalt viscosity at a constant temperature. The results also showed that specimens containing nano-silica have a smaller phase angle difference and greater complex shear module [26]. Fakhri et al. investigated the impacts of using Styrene-
Butadiene-Styrene (SBS) polymer on hot asphalts. The results obtained from the study shows that using 5% of SBS polymer can increase the indirect tensile strength of the modified specimen [27]. A study was conducted to evaluate the performance of OGFC in the laboratory with various grading and types of additives by Kandhal and Mallick. Both SBS and SB were added to the asphalt binder at 4% by weight of binder. In this study, all of the modified binders had significantly lower abrasion loss than the unmodified binder. The use of both polymer-modified binder and fiber canminimize the abrasion loss and thus increase the durability of OGFC [28]. Lastra-González et al. studied the effect of poly propylene fiber on asphalt mixture. In this research, 1% poly propylene was changed by 1% rock materials. It was indicated that using polypropylene fiber increased the stiffness of the modified specimens by 60% compared to the control (non-modified) specimen [29]. In addition, this fiber improved changes in mixtures surfaces characteristics; as though, the modified asphalt mixtures by polymer had less friction resistance than the control specimens [30]. In another research, Davar et al. studied the effect of basalt fiber and diatomite powder on fatigue life and tensile strength of hot asphalt. Regarding this research, using basalt fibers increased indirect tensile strength of asphalt mixtures in low temperatures. Also The reinforcement effects of basalt fiber to the fatigue resistance are evaluated. The direct tension test results show that with an appropriate content, the tensile strength of the asphalt binder is improved with the use of basalt fiber. The basalt fiber also restrains the axial strain and increases the stiffness of the asphalt mixtures [31].
Due to the deficiency and low strength of OGFC mixtures, in this study the glass and basalt fibers, SBS polymers, nano-silica were used to modify on OGFC mixtures and the impacts of modification were investigated. To accomplish the objectives, the performance of modified asphalt mixtures in terms of cracking, raveling, moisture sensitivity and hydraulic conductivity were examined Furthermore, the level of the porousness of OGFC mixtures, durability and percentage of voids is also investigated.

sections.heading: 2.1. Aggregates
sections.text: In asphalt mixture, aggregates may constitute about 70–75% by volume or 90– 95% by weight. The main skeleton of porous asphalt mixtures consists of coarsegrained aggregated with larger size than 4.75 mm. Aggregate properties thought to be important in the absorption process that includes aggregate size gradation, surface chemical composition of the aggregate and surface roughness [32]. Crushed limestone aggregates must be stiff, firm, durable, clean, cube shaped, and devoid of any organic, clay, schist materials and soil cover, and loose grains. The fine-grained content must also be able to fill the void spaces between coarse aggregates in such a way that it does not affect the interconnecting condition. The aggregates used in the present study were subjected to various tests according to AASHTO standard method. The filler is a fundamental element in the bituminous mix, as in addition to acting as a ‘‘filler’’, it provides the necessary cohesion between the elements forming the bituminous mastic, thereby increasing the stiffness of the asphalt mixture. Based on Movilla-Quesada et al. research, filler performance in asphalt mixture depends on filler characteristics (such as chemical and mineralogy characteristics), which can influence the adhesion of bitumen [33]. In this study, lime powder was also used as filler in the production of specimens. The grading and Properties of aggregates is presented in Tables 1 and 2.

sections.heading: 2.2. Bitumen
sections.text: Bitumen obtained from the Pasargad Oil refinery, Iran, has 60/70 penetration grade. The characteristics of the base bitumen are presented in Table 3.

sections.heading: 2.3. Lime powder
sections.text: The physical properties of lime powder used in this study are in accordance with Table 4. Due to the chemical reaction between lime and asphalt binder, less acid would be absorbed by aggregates leading to stronger bond between aggregate surface and binder. Besides, the chemical properties and polarity of aggregates would be affected by lime that make better binder-aggregate adhesion.

sections.heading: 2.4. Nano-Silica
sections.text: Nano-silica with physical and chemical properties presented in Table 5 has been used in this study. In a research conducted by Ghasemi et al., 0.5, 1, 1.5 and 2% nano-silica were used in the bitumen modification. The results of the experiments showed that the modified specimens were improved by nano-silica. The best combination of nano-silica used in bitumen is for the specimen modified with 2% nano silica. In this research, 2% (Asphalt mixture weight) nano-silica was utilized to modify the specimen.

sections.heading: 2.5. SBS polymer
sections.text: SBS polymers consist of styrene-butadienestyrene triblock, showing spherical domains formed by the polystyrene blocks within a matrix of polybutadiene. SBS modified bitumen was prepared using a high shear mixer at 160 C and at a speed of 1800 rpm. By reviewing research and articles, Polymer content used was 4.5% by weight of blend. Also, higher bitumen contents have been selected for polymermodified and modified asphalt binder.

sections.heading: 2.6. Glass fibers
sections.text: Due to their excellent mechanical properties, glass fibers offer an excellent potential for asphalt modification. Glass fibers have a high tensile modulus, i.e., about 60 GPa, an elongation of 3–4%, and elastic recovery of 100%. These fibers will not burn, but become soft at 815 C and exhibit decreased stability at temperatures above 315 C. Also, adding glass fibers into asphalt mixtures enhances material strength and fatigue characteristics as well as ductility [34]. The Glass Fibers as shown in Fig. 1, with their physical properties presented in Table 6 have been used in this study. According to the study carried out by Taherkhani, modifying asphalt mixture with 0.2% 0.6% glass fibers increases the performance of the specimen against raveling. Also, Marshall stability of asphalt concrete increased with increasing glass fiber and nanoclay content, and the highest Marshall stability was achieved at 0.2% of fiber content [35] Therefore, In this study, 0.2% glass fiber by weight of mixture was used to modify the specimen.

sections.heading: 2.7. Basalt fibers
sections.text:
The Basalt fiber is an inorganic fiber which uses natural basalt ore as raw material, and the natural basalt ore is crushed to a certain size, then put into a melting furnace, and drawn at 1450 C-1500 C. The fibers typically have a tensile strength slightly higher than E-glass fibers, and many times greater than steel fibers. Moreover, the advantages of basalt compared to glass fiber are thermal stability and chemical resistance [36–38]. In a research conducted by Wenxiao et al., the effect of using Basalt fibers on asphalt mixtures was investigated. It was revealed that using Basalt fibers by 0.15%, 0.3% and 0.45% improved the performance of the spec-
imen. Hence, 0.2% Basalt fibers was utilized to modify the asphalt mixtures in this study Therefore, according to previous studies in this study, basalt fiber with 2% of the weight of the asphalt mixture will be used. The Basalt Fibers is shown in Fig. 2, and their physical properties is presented in Table 7, used in this study.

sections.heading: 2.8. Mixture preparation
sections.text:
In this study, a laboratory review has been carried out regarding the effect of using glass fiber and Basalt, with SBS polymer and nano-silica in porous asphalt. Moreover, lime powder has been used as filler. Lime or liquid anti-strip additives are two regular treatments for mixes that fail to meet moisture susceptibility requirements.
Two binder contents of 5 and 6% were used to produce asphalt concrete mixes in this research. All of the mixes were treated with 0.5% lime (by weight of mixture) as filler and 4.5% of SBS (by weight of mixture). In addition, 2% Nano-silica (by weight of bitumen), and 0.2% glass fiber and basalt fiber (by weight of bitumen) were used to modify mixtures. Therefore, for each of the tests, 10 specimens of OGFC mixture were made and the details of each mixture have been shown in Table 8.
In the first step, nano-silica and SBS must be mixed with bitumen in order to create the specimen. The act of mixing is performed by the Heishier instrument at a high speed shear mixer of 1800 rpm and the temperature of 160 centigrade. This process lasts for 20 min and the modified bitumen is finally obtained. Then, aggregates and lime powder are added to the modified bitumen. Eventually, glass fibers and basalt fibers were added to the mixture.

sections.heading: 3.1. Draindown test
sections.text:
Draindown phenomenon is described as the separation of asphalt itself or a combination of bitumen, fine aggregates, and
additives from the mixture during production, storage, and placement [39].The draindown test was conducted based on AASHTO T305 at a temperature of 160 C for asphalt mixtures [40]. In order to determine the optimal bitumen content, the asphalt mixture is placed in a 229 mm plate with a 50 mm depth. Then, it is placed in an oven for two hours. The plate is taken out after two hours and the bitumen content is determined by observing the appearance of asphalt within the glass plate. For porous asphalt mixtures, the optimal bitumen content is defined in a situation in which mixture pores are not filled.
The test specimens after performing the draindown test of bitumen, are shown in Fig. 3.

sections.heading: 3.2. Permeability test
sections.text: A permeability test is used in order to evaluate the permeability of porous asphalt [41–43]. Two common methods to measure permeability are constant head and falling head, which are according to the ASTM D2434-68 and ASTM PS 129-01 standards. In this study, the falling head method has been applied to test the permeability rate of specimens.

sections.heading: 3.3. Cantabro abrasion test
sections.text: The Cantabro test is an index of the strength of OGFC mixtures against decomposition (e.g. raveling). It is also used as an index to predict the lifespan of pavements [44,45]. Los Angeles Abrasion Machine is utilized to conduct a Cantabro test according to the Tex-245-F standard. In this test Los Angeles Abrasion Machine is used. The percentage of effective empty space is defined as the empty space where the water has access. Because of very high air void contents in the asphalt binder of OGFC, this mixture is prone to hardening at a faster rate than dense-graded hot mix asphalt, which may result in reduction of cohesive and adhesive strength leading to raveling. Therefore, the mix design should be subjected to an accelerated aging test. Aging was accomplished by placing five Marshall specimens compacted with 50 blows in a forced draft oven set at 60 C for 168 h (7 days). The specimens are then cooled to 25 C and stored for 4 h prior to Cantabro abrasion test.

sections.heading: 3.4. Indirect tensile strength (ITS) test
sections.text:
The moisture sensitivity of asphalt directly depends on the performance and strength of the mixture. For investigation of moisture sensitivity and durability of asphalt mixtures against water is performed by the tensile strength ratio (TSR) moisture durability index [46]. The indirect tensile test was conducted on mixtures conditioned in wet and dry conditions. The ratio of saturated indirect tensile strength to dry should be at least 75%.

sections.heading: 4.1. Draindown test
sections.text:
The results obtained from this test are presented in Fig. 4. As the maximum draindown of bitumen should be 0.3 percent of total weight of the asphalt mix. Thus, by investigating Specimens 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 per 5% bitumen, it was found that the effect of basalt fiber per 0.2% in the asphalt mixture is greater than that of glass fiber in reducing the draindown phenomenon. Further, The addition of nano-silica to the control asphalt improved the recovery ability of bitumen [23]. The addition of nano-silica in each of these mixtures enhances the level of bitumen draindown. Therefore, the maximum bitumen percentage per 5% of bitumen for mixture 2 is the best case under draindown test.
On the other hand, with an elevation of bitumen percentages to 6%, in comparison with mixtures 6, 7, 8, 9 and 10, it is observed that for controlling the level of the draindown phenomenon, nano-silica compound should also be used with basalt fiber. In this case, mixture 8 showed the best performance (i.e. 0.3).
It was also found that per both values of bitumen percentage, the use of basalt fiber is more effective in decreasing draindown in comparison with glass fiber in the asphalt mixture. The effect of nano-silica in reducing draindown is considerable in specimens with a higher bitumen percentage (6%).

sections.heading: 4.2. Permeability test
sections.text:
According to the results of the permeability test, as shown in Fig. 5, asphalt permeability decreases with increasing fiber and nanomaterials content. The effect of glass fiber in reducing the permeability of the asphalt mixture is far greater than that of the basalt fiber. Thus, mixtures 3 and 7 have the best bitumen percentage for maximum permeability among the nano-modified asphalt mixtures with fibers. The mixture 3, which has the largest permeability among modified mixtures, shows the minimum value of draindown.
Mixture 7 has a greater permeability in comparison with modified mixture per 6% of bitumen, as its amount of the draindown phenomenon has been large; however, it is not chosen as an optimal specimen because specimen 10 revealed the minimum draindown (i.e. 53) and this mixture is chosen as optimal specimen instead.

Specimen 3 with 5% of bitumen and the compound of basalt and nano-silica had the minimum extent of abrasion, and with increase in the bitumen to 6%, then Specimen 8 is chosen as the best specimen in terms of minimum level of bitumen.
Note that in the specimen 2 with 5% bitumen, the application of basalt fiber has alone caused increased abrasion by up to 8.9%, which is still lower than the allowable level of 25%.
The results of the Canterbro test for the aged asphalt mixtures are shown in Fig. 6 according to their sensitivity to oxidation. Based on the observation, it is still seen that the fiber in mixtures made with both bitumen percentages has caused increased sensitivity to oxidation of the asphalt mixture. The mixtures 3 and 8 are chosen as the best specimens of the modified asphalt terms of the minimum sensitivity to oxidation. The effect of nano-silica on reduction of sensitivity to oxidation is considerable. As a result, the specimen 8 reduced the amount of abrasion by 46% compared to the specimen without nano-silica.

sections.heading: 4.4. Porosity test results
sections.text: Investigation of the porosity diagram of asphalt mix specimens in Fig. 7 shows that in both bitumen percentages, the effect of fiber and nanomaterial causes a decrease in air void of the asphalt mixture. Nevertheless, comparison of specimens 2 and 4 indicates that in comparison with basalt fiber, glass fiber causes further reduction in the air void of the asphalt mixture and in both percentages nano-silica also reduces the air void of specimens. Therefore, specimen 2, containing 5% bitumen, shows the best performance in terms of air void. Furthermore, specimens 7 and 8 also exhibit the best performance among mixtures made with 6% bitumen.

sections.heading: 4.5. ITS test results
sections.text:
Fig. 8 indicates that with a comparison of the specimens 2 and 4 as well as specimens 7 and 9, the effect of glass fiber in enhancing tensile strength is far higher than that of basalt fiber. In both bitumen percentages, nano-silica causes improved tensile strength of the mixture. Specimens 2 and 8, given the minimum and maximum bitumen selected, in terms of having suitable air void and minimum the draindown phenomenon, according to Fig. 4 have greater tensile strength in comparison with the unmodified specimen.
Fig. 9 shows that the moisture sensitivity of the asphalt mixture with glass fiber is far better than that of the basalt fiber, and addition of nano-silica causes further improvement.
With an elevation of bitumen percentages from 5 to 6, Specimen 7 due to reduction of TSR value of 75.9, which is less than 80%, thus it shows the negative effect of basalt fiber.
Specimens 8 and 10 show a comparison between the use of basalt fiber and fiber glass. Although the Specimen 10 is better than sample 8 in terms of sensitivity, according to other abrasion and permeability tests it can be concluded that specimen 8 is the optimum specimen (Table 9).

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
The effect of nano-silica in reducing abrasion and reduction of sensitivity to oxidation is considerable. Addition of nano-silica in each of these mixtures enhanced the level of the draindown phenomenon. On the other hand, it was observed that for controlling the level of the draindown phenomenon, nano-silica compound should also be used with basalt fiber.
The effect of glass fiber in reducing the permeability of asphalt mixture was far greater than that of basalt fiber. The specimen with the largest permeability showed the minimum value of the draindown phenomenon.
The effect of nano-silica in reducing abrasion was considerable, while in contrast, addition of fiber in the asphalt mixture caused elevated levels of abrasion in the asphalt specimens.
It was observed that using fiber in both bitumen percentages caused increased sensitivity to oxidation of the asphalt mixture. Also, the effect of nano-silica on reduction of sensitivity to oxidation was considerable. Moreover, the effect of glass fiber in enhancing tensile strength was far higher than that of basalt fiber. Besides, nano-silica caused improved tensile strength of the mixture.
The moisture sensitivity of the OGFC mixtures with glass fiber was better than that of the basalt fiber, and addition of nanosilica caused further improvement.

metadata.abstractText: Open-graded friction course (OGFC) is a mixture having gap graded aggregate which is used in pavement surfacing. Asphalt mixtures were modified by Nano silica, polymer, basalt fiber and glass fiber. A draindown test, Cantabro test, permeability test and an indirect tensile strength test and moisture susceptibility were used to evaluate the performance of OGFC mixtures. Test results revealed optimum compounds for 0.2% basalt fiber with 2% nano-silica and 4.5% Styrene-Butadiene Styrene (SBS) Polymer. The minimum air voids content of fiber-reinforced OGFC mixtures modified with nanomaterial should be 13% for 6% bitumen. The results showed the effect of nano-silica in reducing abrasion and reduction of sensitivity to oxidation is considerable and the effect of basalt fiber per 0.2% in the asphalt mixture to be greater than that of glass fiber in reducing the draindown phenomenon; and for controlling the level of draindown phenomenon, nano-silica compound should also be used with basalt fiber. It was also found that although the use of basalt fiber is more effective in decreasing draindown in comparison with glass fiber, the effect of glass fiber in reducing the permeability of the asphalt mixture is far greater than basalt fiber. 2019 Published by Elsevier Ltd.
